failureModes.name: Heel Cracking
failureModes.description: A crack forms at the 'Heel' of the stitch bond (where the wire transitions from flat to round).

images.alt: Heel crack in aluminum bond wire
images.caption: Diagram and SEM image showing heel crack formation in Al bond wire at Si chip interface
SEM image showing heel and wedge failure at 100μm scale

rootCauses.mechanism: Work-hardens the heel, making it brittle
A sharp edge on the capillary/wedge cuts into the wire
If the loop comes into the stitch at a steep angle (>30°), the bending stress snaps the heel

symptoms: Wire breaks at stitch heel during pull testing
fixes: Adjust loop trajectory to reduce heel angle

failureModes.name: Cratering
failureModes.description: The silicon or dielectric under the bond pad cracks. The bond pad lifts off, taking a chunk of silicon with it.

images.caption: SEM image showing cratering damage with visible silicon fracture beneath the bond pad

rootCauses.mechanism: Especially problematic with Copper wire due to its hardness
If the bonding frequency matches the resonant frequency of the pad structure, it acts like a jackhammer

symptoms: Bond pad lifts with silicon attached
Visible damage to silicon under pad
Conchoidal fractures (scalloped divots) visible after pad etch
prevention: Use 'Ramp-up' ultrasonic energy (start low, increase slowly)
Use higher frequency (120kHz) which uses less amplitude
Optimize impact force for wire type
Ensure robust pad metallization for Cu wire
fixes: Change ultrasonic frequency to avoid resonance
Switch to softer wire material if possible

failureModes.name: Lift-Off (Peeling)
failureModes.description: The wire bond pops off the pad leaving the pad intact.

images.caption: SEM image showing wire bond lift-off pattern with characteristic surface features
Comparison of failure types: (a) Lift-off, (b) Heel crack, (c) Crack near joint interface

rootCauses.mechanism: Halogens, Flux residue on pad surface prevent proper weld formation
Oxidation on pad surface prevents proper metal-to-metal contact

symptoms: Pad surface appears clean/shiny after lift
Low pull test values with Code 1 failure mode
prevention: Proper storage and handling of components
Minimize time between cleaning and bonding

failureModes.name: Kirkendall Voids
failureModes.description: Micro-voids forming at the interface of Gold wire and Aluminum pads.

images.caption: Corrosion progression showing Au ball detachment from Al pad: (a) Initiation, (b) Propagation, (c) Detachment

rootCauses.mechanism: Au diffuses into Al faster than Al diffuses into Au. This vacancy imbalance creates voids that eventually merge and sever the connection.
Elevated temperatures accelerate the diffusion process and void formation

symptoms: Gradual increase in bond resistance over time
Associated with Purple Plague (AuAl₂) or White Plague (Au₅Al₂) intermetallic formation
prevention: Use barrier metallization between Au and Al
fixes: Cannot be fixed once formed - prevention is key
Redesign with barrier layers or alternative materials
